questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune.

You plan to use Windows Autopilot to provision 25 Windows 11 devices.

You need to meet the following requirements during device provisioning:
• Display the progress of app and profile deployments.
• Join the devices to Azure AD.

What should you configure to meet each requirement? To answer, drag the appropriate settings to the correct requirements. Each setting may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content: correct

comments.content:
Display the progress of app and profile deployments: Enrollment status page
- The Enrollment Status Page (ESP) is used to display the progress of app installations, profile configurations, and policies during Autopilot provisioning. It ensures that devices are configured before users access the desktop.

Join the devices to Azure AD: Deployment profiles
- Deployment profiles control how devices are provisioned with Autopilot, including specifying the device join type (Azure AD Join or Hybrid Azure AD Join). To join the devices to Azure AD, configure the Deployment Profile to "Azure AD joined."

discussion.content: correct
Correct
seems correct

Anyone can explain the answer? I think it should be:
Deployment Profile
Enrollment Status Page
Agreed

questions.question_text:
Your company has a Remote Desktop Gateway (RD Gateway).

You have a server named Server1 that is accessible by using Remote Desktop Services (RDS) through the RD Gateway.

You need to configure a Remote Desktop connection to connect through the gateway.

Which setting should you configure?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The "Connect from anywhere" setting allows you to specify the Remote Desktop Gateway server for the connection. You need to provide the following details under this setting:
1.The RD Gateway server's address.
2. Specify whether to use the RD Gateway credentials for the remote server or provide separate credentials.
This configuration ensures that your Remote Desktop connection routes through the RD Gateway, enabling secure access to the internal server (Server1) from external networks.

Selected Answer: A
A. Connect from anywhere. mr_Eliot " Run MSTSC.exe and check for your self." Did you check it yourself?! Open mstsc.exe and go to tab "ADVANCED" and see below "CONNECT FROM ANYWHERE: Configure settings to connect through Remote Desktop GATEWAY when I am working remotely"!!!!!!!!!!!

Selected Answer: C
Is more specific

Selected Answer: C
Connect from anywhere: This setting is related to enabling RD Gateway but is not where you configure the actual connection settings for using the gateway. 
Connection settings: This is where you configure the RD Gateway settings. You need to enter the RD Gateway server address and possibly other details required for connecting through the gateway.

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A. When you click Advanced Tab (mstsc) --> Connect from anywhere and then configure RD Gateway

comments.content:
Correction answer is C

If the question is about configuring the Remote Desktop Connection application (MSTSC.exe), then "Connection settings" (option C) would be more appropriate.
If the question is about ensuring the connection goes through the RD Gateway, then "Connect from anywhere" (option A) is the correct choice.

discussion.content:
A

if you're configuring the Remote Desktop Connection application (MSTSC.exe) on your local machine to connect through a Remote Desktop Gateway (RD Gateway), you typically need to ensure that the "Connect from anywhere" setting is enabled.

Selected Answer: C
Answer is correct. Run MSTSC.exe and check for your self.

comments.content: This slight semantics. There is a "connection settings" section on the General tab that allows you to Save, Save As, or Open an RDP file, BUT, on the Advanced tab, there is a "connect from anywhere" section that you must click Settings to get into to then finally see your generically named "Connection Settings." That is a bridge to far for me. I am going to choose to go to the section that you need to actually CLICK on to get to that second page. I vote A.

discussion.content: Chatgpt answer is C

comments.content: Yeah.. because AI is always right -.-
Yes, I agred with you, stop using chatgpt or any AI

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Silly question but I'd have to say Connect From Anywhere wins it for me. Within the Connect From Anywhere there are two options, namely, Connection Settings and Logon Settings. If you selected Connection Settings, you'd be ignoring Logon Settings. I think together they both make up the requirement in the question above.

Selected Answer: A
Connect from Anywhere makes more sense here
Well to be fair, I am going with A, Under Connect from Anywhere is "Settings" and NOT Connection Settings
Correct

Stupid question.
"Connection settings" is UNDER "Connect from Anywhere" \ "Settings"

Selected Answer: A
SEEMS CORRECT
So is it Connect from anywhere or Connection settings?

Selected Answer: C
Option A, "Connect from anywhere," is a general setting that allows connections from any network. However, when you are specifically dealing with connecting through a Remote Desktop Gateway (RD Gateway), you typically need to configure the RD Gateway server settings.

So, for a Remote Desktop connection to go through an RD Gateway, you usually configure the "Connection settings" (Option C), not "Connect from anywhere" (Option A).
Confirmed.

In the Remote Desktop Connection dialog box, click Options to expand the dialog box and view settings.
On the Advanced tab, under "Connect from anywhere", click Settings to access.
Agreed

Selected Answer: A
Definitely it's A

Selected Answer: A
A is correct.

Selected Answer: A
A is right

Selected Answer: A
Preinstall
Correct
AGREED
Agreed

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) deployment share.

You plan to deploy Windows 11 by using the Standard Client Task Sequence template.

You need to modify the task sequence to perform the following actions:
• Format disks to support Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI).
• Create a recovery partition.

Which phase of the task sequence should you modify?

discussion.content: Provided answer is correct. There is no mention of depoloying computer via network.
CORRECT

Answer is correct:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/deploy-windows-mdt/deploy-a-windows-10-image-using-mdt

I think the question is wrong and about WDS:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/wds-boot-support

The operating system deployment functionality of Windows Deployment Services (WDS) is being partially deprecated. Starting with Windows 11, workflows that rely on boot.wim from installation media or on running Windows Setup in WDS mode will no longer be supported.

When you PXE-boot from a WDS server that uses the boot.wim file from installation media as its boot image, Windows Setup automatically launches in WDS mode. This workflow is deprecated for Windows 11 and newer boot images. The following deprecation message is displayed:
MDT can do windows 11 images, I use MDT and Windows 11 can be used. However, this was only tested using .wim files and not the entire set of installation media
Wouldn't you need wds to do this?

comments.content:
Regardless, of whether or not the question meant Windows 10 or 11 it Install WDS services doesn't seem necessary based on the information in the question. The only thing WDS would add is the ability for target computers to boot into the PE over the network as opposed to using a USB/DVD installation media to deploy Windows. It doesn't say admin effort has to be minimized, only that it had to be deployed to 100 computers via the MDT that was installed on the on prem server. 

1. Create deployment share on MDT server
2. Add image to deployment share
3. Create a task sequence

following these steps, MDT will generate PE Lite touch boot images that can be use to create installation media used to boot and deploy the 100 devices OR that same image can be imported to a WDS server to allow those same computers to boot from the image over the network instead of having to bring physical installation media to each device. The WDS part does not fit with the goal of the question but the other 3 steps do achieve that.

Agreed. From the link:

"The following OS versions are supported for deployment with this build of MDT:
Windows 10, version 1809
Windows 10, version 1803
Windows 10, version 1709
Other supported versions of Windows 10
Windows 8.1
Windows 7
Windows Server 2019
Windows Server 2016
Windows Server 2012 R2
Windows Server 2012
Windows Server 2008 R2

Note:
MDT doesn't support Windows 10 ARM64 devices, Windows 11 and Windows Server 2022 operating systems."

However, despite the official docs (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/configmgr/mdt/release-notes#supported-platforms) from 10/03/2022, just 10 days later a user posted a guide outlining how to do exactly this (https://4sysops.com/archives/deploy-windows-11-with-microsoft-deployment-toolkit-mdt/) so perhaps the Microsoft documentation is just incomplete still.

discussion.content:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/configmgr/mdt/release-notes#supported-platforms
Should that be Windows 10 because all research states that MDT doesn't support Windows 11 including the link above.
Agreed

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

Your network contains an Active Directory domain.

You install the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) on a server.

You have a custom image of Windows 11.

You need to deploy the image to 100 devices by using MDT.

Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.

//IMG//

You have the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) installed.

You install and customize Windows 11 on a reference computer.

You need to capture an image of the reference computer and ensure that the image can be deployed to multiple computers.

Which command should you run before you capture the image?

discussion.content: Correct
CORRECT

Selected Answer: C
Sysprep (System Preparation) prepares a Windows client or Windows Server installation for imaging. Sysprep can remove PC-specific information from a
Windows installation (generalizing) so it can be installed on different PCs.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/sysprep--system-preparation--overview

Selected Answer: C
Sysprep

Selected Answer: C
Correct
